Posts.Content: Hi Sept78 and Mrs50,  I had my last chemo on 1st Nov, and am now 3/4 of the way through radiotherapy.  The chemo already seems like a crazy dream! I had one FEC without a PICC line and got sore veins like yourselves. I then asked for a PICC line and used it for the other 5 chemo doses (2 x FEC and 2 x Docetaxel).  My chemo unit were very happy to organise that.  Having had surgery first I only had one arm they could use for chemo.  For me there were pros and cons with the PICC line, but I didn't have any hospital issues.  It did completely save my veins from any further damage and of course comes into its own on chemo day, which gives some peace of mind!  For me the disadvantages were: It restricted what I did physically during the months of chemo because I was worried about dislodging the line or causing bleeding.  I was told no vacuuming, no ironing, no swimming etc.  So I stopped all my exercising except walking for the months of the chemo, even the good weeks.  (Mind you, I think I could have been more gung ho, and you can't go swimming or to exercise classes anyway most of the time, due to risk of infections.)  Having to go into the chemo ward every week to have the PICC line flushed and dressing changed. That's lots of extra visits. Difficult to bathe or shower. It's not a great summer look! But if I had to have chemo again I would get a PICC line again.  Although on the anti-PICC front, the vein damage I got from the one FEC went away after a few weeks without any creams.  So maybe if you have two arms to use you could alternate them, to give the veins 6 weeks to recover. Sorry that's a mixed review from me! Very best of luck with your chemo experience! best wishes, Betty xxx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hiya, just to chip in that I'm on Crescent brand.  I've only been on it for 5 weeks, but it's been fine for me so far.  I haven't tried any others. Betty xxx
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Hiya, just to chip in that I'm on Crescent brand.  I've only been on it for 5 weeks, but it's been fine for me so far.  I haven't tried any others. Betty xxx
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Happy new year of walking everyone! I haven't posted many walks so far because I don't remember to take any photos - but will make more of an effort in January.  Rest assured I have been walking! I normally do one short and one long dog walk a day, plus a 30 min fast walk without the dogs.   The walking does make a big difference to my energy levels, mood and health. Today I walked up 6 floors of stairs at the hospital because the one working lift was being so slow.  Had to stop half way - I am totally out of practice!  But there was a lovely view from the Chemo unit while I was having my Herceptin and Zolendronic acid love Betty xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hello all - I remembered to take some photos today on the dog walk!  (The older one didn't want to come out very far today, so I took him home and came out again with the puppy for a longer one.)   Now got to do some vacuuming so I can put down some more anti-flea spray ... sigh .., then dentists to have a filling replaced.  Another fun day! love Betty xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Sunnyone yes my puppy is a cavapoo too!  They do look exactly the same! Her mother is a black miniature poodle and her dad is a tri coloured cavalier.  She's 7 months old.  Has kept me distracted while off for months with the cancer treatment. love Betty xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Been out for the morning dog walk, despite wind and rain.  Was quite nice out there really - at least its not cold.  Forgot to take my phone/camera, so here are the dogs afterwards:
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I’m enjoying lots of time walking beaches in Cornwall at the moment. Here is hubbie and dogs: And me: Well done everyone who made it to Birmingham today.  I hope to make the next gathering.  Love and good vibes to everyone on the site, especially those not well at the moment, waiting for results/appointments, or wrestling with making decisions.  Betty xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Wow I’m so impressed people are picking up their hobbies again. I was in Rock Choir, but gave it up a few years ago.  Keen to restart with Rock Choir or a different choir - I really must get started on that. Tai Chi I started last year trying to teach myself from a DVD but I think it would be better for me to go to a class.  Must start investigating that too! Yoga I’m better progressed on - I have an app on my phone that I follow along, and have identified a class to start.  I’ve stuck with daily meditation though which I’m pleased about. Last day in Cornwall was yesterday- we went on the coast path above Trebarwith Strand because the tide was too high to stay long on the beach. Lovely view
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Happybird, I'm so sorry you're in this situation. We never met, but I really feel for you.   I'm sure its really tough for you coming to terms with the news, after all you've already gone though, and switching to being the carer this time.  I was the carer for my husband who had lung cancer a few years ago, which he survived, but I would have preferred to be the patient rather than the carer.  Big hugs, and try to look after yourself enough too, so you can stay well. Betty xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Val36, so sorry you have to make that decision without a clear recommendation by your oncologist.   It seems to me that if you take chemo they monitor your side effects, and you can always stop if they’re intolerable.  You don’t know what side effects you’ll get.  There are people on this forum who have done that (ie tried it then stopped before the end.) Whereas if you don’t take the chemo and then the cancer does return you might regret not trying it.  There are people in this forum who are in that category too.  Best of luck with your decision, Betty xxx
Posts.Title: What to do for the best

Posts.Content: Hi all, So, I'm on my second chemo dose, and day 2 I was very fuzzy headed and spent most of the day resting in bed, but did liven up a bit in the evening.  Not vomited this time, perhaps due to the 4 different anti-sickness pills I'm now prescribed. I unfortunately did forget one pill yesterday, and missed one today (day 3) as ended up on an extended wig shopping trip without them, but hopefully the other pills will pull me through.  Went bright red and also started the white blood cell boosting injections today, which I hate, and due to a prescription error I need to go back to the hospital to get 2 more by Wednesday - I really do! Rashly have bought a cavapoo puppy that we're collecting tomorrow, as it seems like a good time overall to train up a new puppy while I'm home most of the time for 6 or 7 months on chemo and radiotherapy.  Slightly concerned about how tiring it'll be when I'm under the influence of the chemo, but my eldest daughter has offered to do the overnight and early morning shifts and is off school for 6 weeks soon, plus other daughter and hubbie will be able to help in the evenings and weekends. We have an elderly cavalier dog, who I suspect will be trying to train the puppy to leave him alone.  All this dog activity will be a good distraction for me hopefully. Hang in there chemo buddies, we will get through this. love and hugs, Betty xxx
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi all,  Sorry I haven’t written for a few days. It’s now difficult to respond properly to everyone - so just to say I’m thinking of you all out there.  I’m on day 13 of cycle 2 and the side effects are nearly over for me, so that’s lucky.  I’m mainly just left with sore mouth and tiredness. My PICC line has been quite a pain. I’m constantly adjusting the bandages to try to make it more comfortable and I would be a lot more active with that arm if I wasn’t worried about the PICC line coming out or bleeding.  But it will come into its own next week for the cycle 3 blood test and chemo next week! The new puppy is keeping me busy - she is into everything and only partially toilet trained! I will attempt to post a picture now.  Take care everyone  love and hugs Betty x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hello Karen 234, join the club! My suggestions on what to take to chemo ... Take somebody with you to keep you company and do the driving.  I take something to read and a cold drink (because of the hot weather) but don't need them because the nurses are so busy chatting and offering you drinks and biscuits and the TV is always on.  My hubbie and I happened to be there across lunch time on my first EC and we got free lunch and ice cream!   I take something warm to put on for if I get cold sitting, but haven't used that either as both days have been really warm.  Oh and mobile phone obvs for trying to keep up with the July chemo chat! Without the cold cap, the chemo sessions have been quite quick for me so far.  take care, and best of luck, Betty xxx
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi all, I’m in the July chemo club too! I’m on day 13 of my first chemo cycle. Next dose on 12th July. I’m on EC for 3 x 3 week cycles, then Doxetaxel 3  x 3 week cycles in parallel with Herceptin for 18 x 3 weeks.  I was diagnosed on 3rd May with a 17mm IDC, and had WLE and SNB surgery on 10th May to remove it. I’m grade 3, triple positive, but it hadn’t reached the lymph nodes.  So my hair hasn’t started falling out yet, but I’ve been busy stocking up on scarves, hats and wigs ready because I hear it might start tomorrow! I’m getting a PICC line put in on 11th as I’ve seen such rave reviews for them on this site and I wasn’t offered a port.  My hand and arm veins really struggled with the first chemo dose, and I needed needles again the next day for blood tests, anti sickness and saline drip, so I decided it’ll be worth the PICC line in the long run. My hospital isn’t too far away to go back every week to have it flushed and redressed.  I didn’t fancy the cold cap having seen a video of it and because it seems to have a low chance of fully working.  And I’m also preoccupied about diet, and have shopped for a Mediterranean diet this week. So many fruit and veg I couldn’t fit them all in the fridge . Take care everyone, and stay strong. Liz x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi HappyFeet1, for me the onco radiotherapy planning and the radiotherapist radiotherapy planning meetings were two separate days, but maybe yours will be combined. The oncologist  just talked about the overall plan and got me to sign a consent form.  The radiographer meeting was to measure me up, scan me and tattoo me.  Exciting to have more people on the radiotherapy train - it’s so quiet! I’m starting on Wednesday.  Waiting around till then trying to avoid online bargain shopping, but started Christmas shopping!  Betty xxx
Posts.Title: November 2018 Radiotherapy Thread

Posts.Content: Got my chemo #2 done this afternoon, and all went fine.  I had the PICC line this time which did make it nicer, and an extra anti sickness pill beforehand  Back home, feeling a bit strange, but otherwise OK.  2 down, 4 to go ! Hope all the other chemos today went well  Betty x

A lot of my hair has fallen out and I’ve had it cut short now, but my scalp is really sore.  Would it be less sore if I shaved the rest off?  Betty x

Posts.Content: Maggie-Gaudigirl, it sounds like its all happening really fast for you, although in some ways that's good - at least you're not sitting around waiting. It took me a few weeks to come to terms with my diagnosis as it all happened so fast.  On the one hand you do know its really happening, and on the other hand you don't really believe it! Good luck for this week's appointments.  It helps me to just think very short term when I can, so as not to get swamped by all the stages and future appointments at once. take care, Betty xxx

Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Hi oks yes my puppy is a cavadoodle. Her mum is a black poodle and her dad a multi colour cavalier like my older dog.  So sorry to hear your dog died just after chemo started - that’s dreadful So sad   take care with the rest of the chemo  Betty x
Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: The same happened to me - I too was surprised when the radiographer said I had clips marking where my tumour was which were put in during the surgery. Nobody told me that! I also asked if they’d set off security scanners at airports but apparently not ! My radiotherapy update is that I’ve done my planning session, although they couldn’t plan the boost treatment as my oncologist couldn’t make it.  I think because of that the radiotherapy start date has now been moved a week to 28th Nov. So I have my penultimate session on Christmas Eve and then the last one on day after Boxing Day. I’m lucky to have found out that the dates moved, it was only because I happened to phone them to check some appointment times ! I’m all set with Aveeno cream, and have been tattooed.  I’m off to Cornwall tomorrow for a few days for a quick holiday before the radiotherapy starts. Should be really nice . take care everyone,  Betty xxx

Posts.Content: Hi earwig o so sorry to hear about the aborted PICC line insertion. Sounds a nightmare. Horrible at the best of times. good luck for tomorrow’s canula - don’t they ever insert a canula for the chemo in your elbow veins - or are they just as tiny? love Betty x
